p: Our results also show that a community-based approach to manage the exchange of material between different growers over successive seasons would increase the probability of success for the introduction of partially-resistant or tolerant varieties ( S2 Appendix). Care would need to be taken to monitor the effects of partial resistance on pathogen build-up as well as the risks of unintended consequences such as distributing varieties with increased susceptibility to other cassava diseases such as cassava mosaic disease [ 7, 12, 25, 32]. The probability of success in limiting disease spread and crop loss would be enhanced by augmenting a clean-seed scheme with roguing of infected plants and isolation of uninfected fields [ 13].
